p: IFN-I were first discovered more than 60 years ago as antiviral substances produced by influenza virus-infected cells, capable of markedly inhibiting viral replication in target cells [ 9]. These cytokines were the firsts to be cloned and have been extensively used in patients with some viral diseases [ 10] and cancer (IFN-α) [ 11], and in the treatment of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS) (IFN-β, [ 12]). Indeed, IFN-I are pleiotropic factors endowed with multiple activities, including both a broad-spectrum antiviral activity [ 9, 10] and a remarkable antiproliferative and immunoregulatory function [ 13].
